issue.message: "format()" looks like a call; surround with backtics in string to display as symbol, e.g. \`format()\`
issue.errorLine1: explanation = "Since Timber handles String.format automatically, you may not use String#format().",

issue.message: "format()" looks like a call; surround with backtics in string to display as symbol, e.g. \`format()\`
issue.errorLine1: explanation = "Since Timber handles String#format() automatically, use this instead of String concatenation.",

issue.message: In unit tests, use the fullwidth dollar sign, `＄`, instead of `$`, to avoid having to use cumbersome escapes. Lint will treat a `＄` as a `$`.
In unit tests, use the fullwidth dollar sign, `＄`, instead of `$`, to avoid having to use cumbersome escapes. Lint will treat a `＄` as a `$`.
In unit tests, use the fullwidth dollar sign, `＄`, instead of `$`, to avoid having to use cumbersome escapes. Lint will treat a `＄` as a `$`.
In unit tests, use the fullwidth dollar sign, `＄`, instead of `$`, to avoid having to use cumbersome escapes. Lint will treat a `＄` as a `$`.

No need to call `.trimMargin()` in issue registration strings; they are already trimmed by indent by lint when displaying to users. Instead, call `.indented()` on the surrounding `java()` test file construction
